channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Assad Relative Is Arrested After Protests Over a Killing
item.description: Hundreds of protesters called for the man’s punishment over suspicions that he killed an army officer in a traffic dispute.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: U.S. Lawyer Is Killed
item.description: The lawyer, John Ralston Pate, 70, was found dead Sunday in an apartment in an affluent neighborhood of eastern Caracas.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Chinese Christians Resist Government Plan to Remove Crosses
item.description: China’s campaign has provoked sometimes spectacular protests, including church members who have climbed spires to shield crosses.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Plan to Redraw Internal Boundaries Prompts Violent Protest in Nepal
item.description: Two people were killed and six wounded in clashes with the police over a proposal linked to the drafting of a new constitution.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: For Many in Spain, a Heralded Economic Recovery Feels Like a Bust
item.description: The majority of the country’s new jobs are part-time and offer low wages, experts say, and some employees are expected to do hours of unpaid work.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angel Puyalón and his wife, Maria Jesús Júdez, at home in Zaragoza, Spain, in June. Mr. Puyalón was unable to find work, and the couple worried about losing their home.

item.title: German Journalists Celebrate as Treason Inquiry Is Dropped
item.description: The investigation of Markus Beckedahl and André Meister for publishing secret government plans for Internet surveillance had stoked a public uproar.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Britta Pedersen/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: André Meister, left, and Markus Beckedahl last week in Berlin.

item.title: Drawings of Police Torturing a Suspect Captivate China
item.description: A man wrongly convicted in a shooting death hired an artist to depict scenes of the police tactics he said were used to force him to confess to a crime he did not commit.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: “Forcing coffee down the nose and mouth.”

item.title: Gun Battle Erupts Outside U.S. Consulate in Istanbul
item.description: The attack was one of several violent episodes across the country, which some attributed to an uptick in clashes between Turkish security forces and Kurdish militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Turkish special forces after clashes with assailants in Istanbul on Monday.

item.title: Police in Bangladesh Kill 6 Suspected of Tiger Poaching in Shootout
item.description: The police described the raid on Sunday in the Sundarban mangrove forest as the beginning of a larger crackdown on poaching.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Observatory: Climate Change Could Harm British Butterflies
item.description: Six species of butterflies in Britain will face local extinction by 2050 because of climate change, a new study reports.
item.dc:creator: SINDYA N. BHANOO
item.media:description: The green-veined white butterfly is among six species of butterfly that could face extinction in Britain by 2050 as a result of climate change.

item.title: Nusra Front Announces Withdrawal From Front Line Against ISIS in Syria
item.description: The Nusra Front, the Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda, said it disagreed with plans by Turkey and the United States to clear the Islamic State from an area along the Turkish border.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Afghan President Points Finger at Pakistan After Bombings in Kabul
item.description: After a car bombing on Monday continued a wave of attacks, President Ashraf Ghani accused Pakistan of failing to prevent Taliban gatherings in its territory.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Police officers at the site of a deadly car bombing near the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Monday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Protecting the Farmers of France
item.description: Anger has focused on produce coming into France from neighboring countries in the European Union that, in their view, has undercut French food prices.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Livestock breeders blocked access roads last month in the Normandy region in northwestern France to protest a drop in meat and milk prices.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Drawings Depict a Former Chinese Prisoner’s Alleged Torture by Police
item.description: Liu Renwang was twice convicted of murder in the 2008 shooting death of a village official in Shanxi Province before he was found not guilty on appeal.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: “Hung up for a day and a night and given electric shocks. One or two hours each time, causing me to lose consciousness.”

item.title: Global Health: Catching Up With a Childhood Killer, Diarrhea
item.description: A movement is afoot to update outdated standards for treating childhood diarrhea.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Abshira Abdukadir, a four-year-old girl in Somalia, being treated for diarrhea, which kills 700,000 infants each year.

item.title: Mali Selmensti Journal: A Ukrainian Border Town Once Fenced by Soviets Blossoms Into a Shopper’s Paradise
item.description: Since 2005, a pedestrian crossing has drawn a surge of Slovakian visitors to a small Ukrainian village, where consumer goods are considerably cheaper.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers from Velke Slemence, Slovakia, prepared to cross the border after shopping in the Ukrainian village of Mali Selmentsi.

item.title: Ex-Officer in Chinese Army Receives Suspended Death Sentence in Graft Case
item.description: The inquiry into the former senior officer, Lt. Gen. Gu Junshan, found that he had bought military promotions and pocketed millions of dollars through procurement contracts.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Indonesian Court Rejects Sex Abuse Suit Against International School
item.description: The plaintiffs had claimed that janitors and educators repeatedly abused a 6-year-old boy at a prestigious private school popular with expatriates.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Gao Yu, Jailed Chinese Journalist, Is Said to Be Receiving Good Medical Care
item.description: She was taken to a specialist civilian hospital outside the medical system run by the police for tests that revealed cardiovascular problems, her lawyers said.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Gao Yu, in a photo from June 9, 2012, is serving a seven-year prison term for allegedly leaking state secrets.

item.title: South Korea Accuses the North After Land Mines Maim Two Soldiers in DMZ
item.description: The South Korean military said that two of its soldiers were wounded by mines planted near their post on the South’s side of the Demilitarized Zone.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: The Defense Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers on patrol near the site of land mine explosions in the Demilitarized Zone last week. One soldier lost a leg; the other lost both.
